urn:contentItem:5V98-J4B1-JC8V-41Y4-00000-00More Than Skin Deep2018-05-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:46ZLexisNexisREGULARSGlobal SalonPg. 106More Than Skin DeepAndrea Murad

Sonny Singh, senior vice president and general manager of the Financial Services Global Business Unit at Oracle since 2013, talks about legacy systems and how financial services are handling transformative technologies.

Global Finance: Where is Oracle's focus today?

Sonny Singh: While our origins were in database technology, today, we're a broad-based enterprise technology company that delivers applications, platforms and infrastructure technologies globally. We have accumulated IP and built verticals in seven different industries: financial services, communications, utilities, hospitals, retail, health and construction. For each of these verticals we have global business groups focused on product strategy, engineering, M&A, sales, implementation and customer service. We have 22,000 people working worldwide across these verticals, and financial services is the largest, with more than 9,000 employees.

GF: How is the finance sector in taking up new technology?

Singh: Financial services were early adopters. They were first to truly use computing to enhance business. They invested aggressively and built their own proprietary systems before many of the transformative technologies like AI, Big Data, IoT and social media that are mainstream now even existed. Now, precisely because financial-services were early adopters, they have legacy systems that are devoid of these technologies.

GF: How do you solve the problem of being an early adopter?

Singh: To catch up and be able to evolve at a fast clip, systems need to have an architecture that can change very quickly, that's modular. Our digital and data architectures are constructed this way. They can be absorbed in a progressive fashion into the financial institution's business technology framework. We also make these components available through well-defined APIs, allowing the more progressive banks to operate in an ecosystem with fintechs and Big Tech. There's an emerging ecosystem of financial service providers, and open banking for retail and corporate is an important aspect that banks need to think about.

GF: What are some of the drivers shaping technology adoption?

Singh: We see people get caught up by 'buzz' around certain technologies, or sometimes fear of missing out (FOMO), which can lead to fragmented technology adoption. We find that thoughtful evaluation is better for innovation. Banks also have to increasingly comply with more regulations. Regulations evolve and change, and as businesses address each regulation they end up with silos of data. Managing this data with a well-defined information architecture helps not only with compliance, but also provides opportunities to monetize the data in areas such as relationship pricing and personalized product offers.

GF: How are user expectations about technology changing?

Singh: The word "digital" has passed its prime as a differentiator. Being digital is expected, a given. We conducted a survey with 5,700 respondents in 13 markets, and 81% of their business interactions were already digital. Every company now has a digital interface, and customer satisfaction with digital at the basic level is very high.

However, once you get past the simpler transactions, such as depositing checks, to more complex transactions-loans or mortgages-satisfaction with digital plummets, with 30% of our survey respondents looking at alternatives. Simpler transactions are being addressed by digital experiences, while more complex processes are still being handled in the traditional way.

Banking used to have a strong human element. In corporate banking, where banks serve large corporations, technology is not pervasive across all the functions; there is still a lot of human interaction. However, when you step down to lower market tiers, B2B and B2C are very similar. This is where the banks need to drive digital transformation, reduce friction and deliver a better customer experience. The digital experience needs to be more than skin deep.

urn:contentItem:5YJN-19V1-JCMN-Y0PR-00000-00More thoughts on what the virus might bring about2020-03-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:46ZLexisNexisMore thoughts on what the virus might bring aboutJohnathan Pearce (London)

Mar 31, 2020( Samizdata: http://www.samizdata.net Delivered by Newstex) Dr Stephen Davies [1]of the Institute of Economic Affairs likes to make various political/economic predictions, such as on Facebook, and he claims much of our political landscape has changed in ways that shred traditional markers on the map, saying that much of the argument now is no longer between those who want a Big State or a Small One, but about culture and identity. I like and agree with a lot of what he says, but I also think that the recent crisis, and the shock of what it says about the powers of the State, might - I hope - jolt people into realising that we libertarians, banging on about autonomy, property rights and so on, aren't as irrelevant as is fashionable to claim. The Big State/Small State difference still counts for a lot.

This argument should be made. Free societies, as we can point out, are often better at stepping up to change and emergencies than states often are. Not everyone worships at the altar of socialised medicine. And boy, have we learned the value of free press and scrutiny, if only by seeing what happens in China, when those things don't exist. Consider, even Formula 1 motor racing[2], that symbol of toxic masculine love of going very fast in noisy cars, is using its technical skills to meet the pandemic challenge. Libertarians should point out how entrepreneurial gusto, not the clunky hand of Whitehall, is what needs to be celebrated. And we certainly need to challenge the narrative of how marvellous China has been in locking things down. Turns out that it has been a shitshow.[3] Dr Davies has given a list of trends and forces he thinks will accelerate and turn as a result, and some of his predictions make me alarmed, others less so. Here are some of my own predictions. Dear readers: do add your own. Here goes: A big push to divert supply chains from China; more diversification around this. Maybe some pullback from just-in-time inventory but I don't expect a total shift - the losses in efficiency and living standards are too big. Less business travel and some tourism via air; more requirements that passengers carry medical data with them. Airport security to increasingly entail 'medical security' and there will be demands that airports are more hygienic with cleaner air systems. Continued 're-shoring' of some manufacturing. It is happening already because making stuff locally is getting easier with modern tech. There will be pressure to monetise the enormous amounts of public debt. We could have a Japan-style stagnation lasting for two decades. Not sure if we get hyperinflation. Expect more commentary about gold, the need for hard money, etc. Far more telecommuting and remote working. Some central business districts will have to adjust; some skyscrapers will struggle to fill up. Suburbs and cars are back:[4] who wants to live in a cramped city and rely on unhealthy, crammed public transport if you can live in a nice house, work from home and have a garden? The anti-car lobby has lost - people are glad they have cars. Issue: will the planning system free up to allow lots more homes with gardens etc to be built? I hope so. The 'woke' agenda is losing a lot of steam. It was happening already. Even remote learning will dent traditional educational attendance and power structures. That is a good thing. The European Union and other transnational organisations, including the World Health Organisation, have been useless, and it turns out in the WHO's case, all too cozy to China over Taiwan.[5]Some red tape will be rolled back; if people are going to have to put up with more nannying and state control in some areas they will want liberalisation elsewhere. Look at how some regulations have been canned to deal with the crisis. That could become permanent. The actions of UK and other police in this pandemic have caused very bad publicity for the cops. It was bad already. It is getting worse. Scientists who claim to have all the answers and claim the science is 'settled' will encounter even more resistance. In a funny way this virus is bad news for the dark Greens. Extinction Rebellion's vision of life has been rammed down people's throats these past few weeks. Attacks on Big Tech and demands for anti-trust will wane. The internet has had a good crisis. It kept us going. The value of people with vocational skills, earned without vast sums of student debt, will appreciate; the education 'bubble' of arts grads with high debt/lower salary will burst. This will also hurt the 'woke' culture and the nonsense of what's been happening on our campuses. Identity politics is not going away without a fight, however. Classical liberals/libertarians haven't really woken up fully to how much the victories of the 80s, 90s and even some of the Noughties have been compromised, sometimes by sheer complacency. We need to wake up, to do more of the intellectual heavy lifting. I hope the present situation galvanises more thought, activism and writing. Celebrity culture looks to be on the back foot. It may return, but the Hollyweird culture is in really serious trouble. Crappy remakes of films, Weinstein, etc, etc. People might actually be healthier: all that focusing on taking a daily walk, eating at home, thinking about 'underlying health conditions', might have a positive effect. It is a wake-up call. Mainstream religions might get a revival. I wonder how many atheists have, sort of, prayed recently. Public sports events, though, will attract sell-out crowds. Imagine if you are a rugby, cricket or football fan and denied the ability to see your teams and in the case of Liverpool, for example, robbed of the ability to be the unchallenged winner of its season. Those fans will be desperate to go back. urn:contentItem:5XB9-3BM1-JBV1-X0PW-00000-00More US states join anti-trust probe of Facebook2019-10-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:46ZLexisNexisMore US states join anti-trust probe of FacebookSan Francisco, Oct 22 2019

New York's top attorney on Tuesday said its investigation into whether Facebook violated anti-trust laws has expanded to include most of the country.

The New York-led probe now includes 45 states along with the capital District of Columbia and the US territory Guam, according to New York attorney general Letitia James.

"Our investigation now has the support of 47 attorneys general from around the nation, who are all concerned that Facebook may have put consumer data at risk, reduced the quality of consumers' choices, and increased the price of advertising," James said in a release.

"We will use every investigative tool at our disposal to determine whether Facebook's actions stifled competition and put users at risk."

The leading online social network has become a popular target for elected officials and those seeking election, with topics of expressed concern ranging from privacy and advertising to Facebook backing a plan to launch Libra cryptocurrency.

"Even the biggest of the big tech companies should be held accountable, and that's what we're seeking to do with this investigation," Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmitt said of the New York-led probe.

Facebook chief Mark Zuckerberg has pledged to "go to the mat" to fight government attempts to break up the social media giant.

Zuckerberg has consistently argued that splitting the company would not address issues raised by critics.

Zuckerberg is scheduled to testify Wednesday on Libra before the House of Representatives.

The House Financial Services Committee said in a statement that Zuckerberg would be the sole witness at the October 23 hearing on "An Examination of Facebook and Its Impact on the Financial Services and Housing Sectors."

The hearing comes as Facebook's planned digital coin Libra faces heavy criticism from regulators and lawmakers in the United States and Europe.

urn:contentItem:5XBK-1WY1-JCBJ-K0XS-00000-00More US States Join Anti-trust Probe Of Facebook.2019-10-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:46ZLexisNexisMore US States Join Anti-trust Probe Of Facebook.

New York's top attorney on Tuesday said its investigation into whether Facebook violated anti-trust laws has expanded to include most of the country.

The New York-led probe now includes 45 states along with the capital District of Columbia and the US territory Guam, according to New York attorney general Letitia James.

"Our investigation now has the support of 47 attorneys general from around the nation, who are all concerned that Facebook may have put consumer data at risk, reduced the quality of consumers' choices, and increased the price of advertising," James said in a release.

"We will use every investigative tool at our disposal to determine whether Facebook's actions stifled competition and put users at risk."

The leading online social network has become a popular target for elected officials and those seeking election, with topics of expressed concern ranging from privacy and advertising to Facebook backing a plan to launch Libra cryptocurrency.

"Even the biggest of the big tech companies should be held accountable, and that's what we're seeking to do with this investigation," Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmidt said of the New York-led probe.

Facebook chief Mark Zuckerberg has pledged to "go to the mat" to fight government attempts to break up the social media giant.

Zuckerberg has consistently argued that splitting the company would not address issues raised by critics.

Zuckerberg is scheduled to testify Wednesday on Libra before the House of Representatives.

The House Financial Services Committee said in a statement that Zuckerberg would be the sole witness at the October 23 hearing on "An Examination of Facebook and Its Impact on the Financial Services and Housing Sectors."

The hearing comes as Facebook's planned digital coin Libra faces heavy criticism from regulators and lawmakers in the United States and Europe.

urn:contentItem:5W7V-3CJ1-JB20-G10D-00000-00Morgan Stanley at Sanford C Bernstein Strategic Decisions Conference - Final2019-05-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:46ZLexisNexis053019a12519321.721Morgan Stanley at Sanford C Bernstein Strategic Decisions Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Ted Pick

Morgan Stanley - Head of Trading & Investment Banking Businesses

Conference Call Participants

* Chinedu Bolu

Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., LLC., Research Division - Former Equity Analyst

Presentation

CHINEDU BOLU, FORMER EQUITY ANALYST, SANFORD C. BERNSTEIN & CO., LLC., RESEARCH DIVISION: Great. We'll get started here. First, I'm delighted to welcome for the first time Ted Pick from Morgan Stanley to the SEC Conference.

For those who don't know Ted, Ted runs the institutional business at Morgan Stanley. Prior to that, he was [in] sales and trading, where he took the equities business to the #1 on The Street by market share. He also performed quite a remarkable turnaround in the Fixed Income business, driving growth in that business while sort of cutting cost and capital.

What Ted will first do is give a brief presentation, sort of, about 10 minutes-ish, and then we'll set down for Q&A. So Ted?

TED PICK, HEAD OF TRADING & INVESTMENT BANKING BUSINESSES, MORGAN STANLEY: Thanks, Christian. Good afternoon. Thanks for inviting Morgan Stanley to this conference.

We have 7 slides today covering 3 topics. Our approach to managing the Institutional Securities group, the performance of the group over the last 5 years, and our growth opportunities.

The first slide is called: Managing to the Bigger Box. You may recall that in 2010, we coined the 9 boxes approach for managing the growth plan for the equities business. Here, we will now adapt that construct for the Institutional Securities business as a whole.

Three major businesses: investment banking, equity sales and trading, and fixed income sales and trading across the 3 geographies. It's a straightforward regional and product matrix, where each partner on the management team is accountable for their box, but also jointly tasked with growing the larger box. In practice, the approach succeeds with the management team that has trust, partnership and cohesion built over time, where the average length of Morgan Stanley service for our ISG operating committees averages 20 years. In proper execution, this bigger box facilitates a seamless offering of our tool kit to clients: advice, capital, liquidity, access and risk management solutions. The management accountability model is dependent on a culture of disciplined risk and resource management and a perpetual reinvestment into our leading technology platform. This is the approach we used to success in building our leading equities business, to reshape and grow our Fixed Income business, and to expand our market share in our investment banking business.

The next slide is a snapshot of our equities division, the first box. Over the last decade, we've built this business to become the industry leader for the last 5 years running. As you can see, $9 billion in revenue last year and 20% to 21% share for the last 3 years against a roughly flattish industry wallet. Financing revenue has contributed meaningfully to our overall growth, a relatively more stable revenue stream, but as you can see from the bottom left, now accounts for half the total.

Our steadfast focus on clients, whether they be established asset managers or new entrants across the 3 major product boxes: cash, prime brokerage and derivatives, in each of the 3 major regions has enabled us to identify and capture opportunity sets. The emergence of quantitative and passive investment strategies are 2 examples where we've been able to capture outside share.

We also build businesses which span multiple boxes. Once folks knew how to operate in their box, we wanted them to bleed into other boxes. Examples include futures and clearing. A decade ago, we were an also-ran in that product. Now we're top 2. We're focused on building our resourcing for our International Wealth Management business in Asia, and we have momentum in our fund services business. This is the administration for alternative asset managers, where we are now an industry leader.

In equities, we apply continued rigor on headcount and resources to ensure we retain an attractive return profile. Importantly, continued investment in Morgan Stanley Electronic Trading, what you may know as MSET, that platform is critical, as technology has transformed the Equity business, borne out of for agency cash business and now leveraged across all of our equities businesses.

And now on to the slide for the fixed income division, where we applied similar principles to address what we saw as the secular challenge of a declining wallet. You will recall that in late 2015, we took steps to restructure that business, withdrawing financial resourcing and headcount. Having then completed that task, we felt that the talent pool, with some additional client coverage and risk management best practices learned from the equities experience would create an integrated sales and trading offering. Importantly, we did not break down the separate cultural identities of the equities and fixed income divisions. Rather we cross-pollinated where it made sense to offer clients a harmonized markets offering.

By way of example, we have offered clients an expanded slate of properly risk-managed financing products, again to give the business a more annuitized feel. And similarly, we have also extended our MSET technology, leveraging the brand and industrial scaling capabilities across sales and trading as a diverse -- a fixed income product set that electronifies or equitizes.

As you can see here, $5 billion of revenue over the last several years against a shrinking wallet means that our share has gone up from 6% meaningfully to 9%.

And in the third business, the investment banking division, a business you know well, here, we've maintained a consistent approach. For strategic mandates, the dialogue demands value add to the C-suite and Boards, providing the highest-quality advice and service. The advisory and underwriting businesses are traditional Morgan Stanley strengths which are dependent on our continuing to develop selectively bolt-on talent to optimize client footprint and opportunity. We have maintained sound franchise and underwriting standards through the cycle. And the results are consistently top 1 to 3 in the advisory and equity underwriting products in each region, with improving share in both products while maintaining our wallet in debt underwriting.

That's history in each of the 9 boxes. And now, this slide is entitled Institutional Securities Going Forward, speaking to the potential for growth in our existing businesses.

In equities, we will continue to pursue our strategy of what I call offensive defense. That is to say building on leading share, mining risk and return in our leading prime brokerage and cash businesses while continuing to invest across our derivatives businesses. Again, opportunities that run across the boxes will get prioritized. In fixed income, our forward approach is defensive offense, where we are focused on maintaining our credible trading footprint while selectively investing in our financing businesses.

While we are mindful of the diversity and complexity of the fixed-income product set, our investment into the lead steer client set has begun to result, as you saw, in meaningful share gains. And in banking, we believe we can continue to monetize the Morgan Stanley franchise: our intellectual capital, with share gains achieved by very selectively adding boots to the ground, that is capacity; and product skills, that is capability, where the opportunities arise.

From the bottom are highlighted 2 difference makers for the success of the bigger box that I described: our integrated investment bank, one of the firm's global presence; the second is ISG's capacity to help deliver one firm to our clients.

Across the range of Institutional Securities businesses, to the client set, our global presence is mission-critical and provides us with revenue, diversity and optionality. The U.S. economy and markets have been and will continue to be substantial drivers of ISG's results. Europe, the U.K. and the Continent both, notwithstanding Brexit trauma, will, of course, continue to be important. But here, we highlight growth in Asia as it becomes increasingly relevant to global strategic activity client flows and, in turn, to Morgan Stanley's success.

The inclusion of China in the MSCI marks an inflection point, making China investing scalable for global investors. We've been focused on leading with content, product and corporate access. Consequently, we are ensuring that we have the people, products and infrastructure in place.

For example, in research, we have lead the way in A-share and Greater China coverage footprint, covering nearly 600 companies, representing 60% of advertised daily volume and over 75% of the MSCI market cap in Greater China. That is China, Hong Kong and Taiwan. We are top 1, 2 in trading Hong Kong Connect, which facilitates north- and south-bound market connectivity. We're deploying more resources to our International Wealth Management business.

Investing in growing wealth in Asia represents a significant opportunity in its own right, of course, given the demographic. But the synergy between high-end wealth and ISG is very large and very real. Bank the entrepreneur and bank the company creates a virtuous cycle.

As you're hearing, research, trading and wealth management are critical in the going public lifecycle. As you can see from the middle IPO volume graph, the acceleration of capital formation in Asia is at hand, and we're well positioned with the #1 position in underwriting Asia-based global IPOs for each of the last 3 years, and now, into 2019.

As we think about the Mainland, we continue to invest time and efforts on our onshore securities joint venture with our partners MS Huaxin Securities as we expect direct access to China will be increasingly important alongside continuing access through Hong Kong.

Japan, too, is a key underpinning of Morgan Stanley's global story. Our unique partnership with our 24% shareholder MUFG makes us a leading player in the market, as you can see by our joint venture's top rankings. We've worked together on over 600 transactions, and we build on that through the cycle.

And finally, the Venn diagram, delivering one firm to our clients. This last slide places ISG in the one firm, firm ecosystem. That is Institutional Securities, wealth management and Investment management.

The differentiated value proposition is as follows: that of a comprehensive distribution platform for clients, spanning institutional to retail, which enhances the service offering. There are various ways in which our major businesses complement each other, sourcing ideas, capital, lending opportunities and further client penetration. While we have made real progress, we still have significant opportunity to leverage our global franchise and will continue to be an area of critical focus.

To conclude, I would leave you with the following. Institutional Securities has achieved success simply by executing for clients, exercising risk and resource discipline, and continuing to invest in technology and talent. The team across the integrated investment bank, which has accomplished this, is an experienced and proven team and a collegial one. We actually get along across the investment bank, which plays to our bigger 9 box. We see further potential for growth servicing clients in our existing businesses by continuing to execute.

And with that, I will now take questions, which hopefully will not stump me from Christian.

Questions and Answers

CHINEDU BOLU: Great. Thank you very much, Ted. Before we dig into Morgan Stanley and the topics you brought up, just step back and macro backdrop. Lots of noise, conflicting signals, when it's U.S.-China, folks worried about the late cycle risks. From your seat, how do you see the macro backdrop?

TED PICK: Well, global GDP growth peaked in the first half of last year, probably in the first quarter. U.S., a little later than that, thanks to the effect of the tax package, but that kind of worked its way through the system. And while confidence was good, it wasn't clear that we were going to grow much beyond that. Nonetheless, the Fed was continuing along. They were hiking. There was continued (inaudible) in the fall. And then the Fed went one too many. They -- the market didn't like that, and we had that very rough fourth quarter. But the Fed, having looked at the data, then pivoted.

And so as difficult as the fourth quarter was, the reality is that the beginning of the new year actually started pretty well. There was a strong recovery bias. It happened so quickly that consumer and corporate confidence actually held in pretty good. And so, while growth is slow -- if you think about the U.S. growth for the first half, it's coming in around trend line at 2%. Lower in the second quarter, given the ins and outs of a higher first quarter, probably somewhere around 0.5%. But nonetheless, for the first half, about 2%. And as I said, confidence has held up pretty good.

But then there's this U.S.-China discussion. And that has increasingly created a risk. S&P trades up 10% on the year, but highly defensively. As you know, financials and cyclicals are for sale. Bond markets inverted. So there's a balancing act now, where on the one hand, we are later in the cycle and growth has slowed, but in fairness, growth had not slow to the point that it was below trend line. But now, we have this potential prolonged situation between the 2 which, if it goes on for the balance of the year, will have an effect on corporate confidence, will draw more volatility into the markets, and we'll have clients sitting on their hands. On the other hand, we can muddle through this. It actually could be a reasonably good second half.

CHINEDU BOLU: I guess in a world where there are offsetting items like that, the one hand trend line growth, as you said, but on the other hand, the bond markets could just send in a different signal, how do you manage the business? Are you more cautious? Are you more opportunistic?

TED PICK: Yes. The answer is both, both. We have a strategy in place. Here are the strategies. In fact, there are clients who will look to have us intermediate risk or to act on a catalyst strategy at moments of dislocation, so we're there for the clients. That's a given. And we've been through these periods before.

On the other hand, when you do think about the fact that we are getting later, you have to be thinking about how you're looking at risk. So when the markets get more volatile, the risk itself reprices. So on the one hand, the growth strategy's in place for each of the 3 businesses, these bigger 9 boxes, but we, too, are focused on expense management. We have a firm efficiency ratio out at 73%, and we're very focused on maintaining that, particularly, if this is prolonged in the second half.

CHINEDU BOLU: Let's just get the current operating environment question out of the way. So as you put all that together, how does that impact the business from activity level so far this quarter?

TED PICK: It's mixed. Again, it's mixed. Some product categories are slower. Cash equity volumes are slower. The equity underwriting business is slower. M&A announcements are slower. On the other hand, until very recently, corporate credit, volumes are actually up. Prime Brokerage balances, which bottomed out in the fourth quarter, have been accelerating during the course of the year. So it really is a mixed bag.

And I'd say, in some respects, we're up against very tough same stores because now, having seen that growth peaked now last year, it's not surprising that we were performing at peak's end. But I'd say, this year, given that the confidence is still there, if the China situation does not worsen, perhaps this will look more like 2017 than 2018, which was actually a pretty good year. But we have to see how the next couple of months play out.

CHINEDU BOLU: Okay. Maybe with a longer-term lens, so if I think post-crisis, you saw a nice spike up in Institutional revenues. Broadly speaking, over time, they've been flat. At least for the industry, even though Morgan Stanley has taken market share. As you look forward, say, over the next 5 to 10 years, how do you think of the growth profile of Institutional business, both at Morgan Stanley and the broader industry?

TED PICK: Yes, it's an important question, Christian, because as we know for many years, the securities business was viewed as reasonably correlated to GDP growth. Then we went through these 2 secular themes of automation and regulation coming out of the crisis. And that clearly took some of the wallet out of the business altogether. We saw that in fixed income. We anticipated that, but it had had a drag on the industry as a whole. But we believe that both regulation and automation, while they will continue to be very much in place, they're much better understood.

And so the way I think about it for us is, in 2014, we had $16.5 billion of revenue against $153 billion of total revenue available to the 9 global competitors. And then last year, we had $20 billion of revenue against $145 billion. So that means, all things being equal, our revenue share went from 11% to 14%. That's a pretty good story. And we actually think there's more share to consolidate as we continue to judiciously grow across these boxes.

But more importantly, and I think critical to your question, I'd like to think that now we will begin the process of being the investment banking securities pool as a whole, begin to resume this correlation to GDP growth. So if you have a view that U.S.-led global economy is going to grow, I'd like to think we would grow in line with that or potentially even greater than that.

CHINEDU BOLU: How do you think of the end markets? So I think about your core business and the institutional asset manager base that feeds a lot of your sales and trading business, any challenges they're having, how does that impact your view on the growth prospects of that -- of your business?

TED PICK: They are struggling with, in fact, some of the same issues that the securities business struggles with, namely automation and regulation, and how to generate profitability and to work on optimizing their income statements. So in a sense, that has come back to us to try to divine ways for them to more efficiently deliver product, to reduce friction costs. And the key to that, of course, has been to have this electronic plan that can help deliver a product efficiently to help them risk-manage. But to replace some of that margin hit, really, there are only 2 ways to go: one is to do more volume, which we have; or second to try to offer other products, which is part of the reason I highlighted some of the ancillary businesses that have become quite large inside of equities, inside of fixed income, financing businesses. What we call mandate businesses like listed and futures and clearing, the fund administration business.

The other thing I would add, though, is we thought it was important to get in the C-suite. If you are talking to the asset managers, as you would any other corporate client, and having a discussion about what they're going to do given that they are going through really extraordinary, strategic change, particularly on the back of facing similar challenges to the ones that we went through, it's the beginning of a good conversation. Do you -- if you're a long manager, do look at long/short? Do you think about developing a quantitative offering? Do you think about trying to get at the A-share market? And once in there with the asset manager at the C-suite level, the word works its way through the system that the firm is acting as a trusted adviser. And that enables us then to get some of these other products in-house as well.

CHINEDU BOLU: Okay. So when we put it all together and you kind of think about what specifically would be the biggest opportunities for Morgan Stanley over the next kind of 5 years, whether it's region or product, kind of how would you maybe stack rank that?

TED PICK: Well, the U.S. will lead the way. It's -- again, it's very hard not to be thinking a lot about Asia. I'm not the bear on Europe that some folks are. Both the continent and the U.K. will find its way as economic powerhouses. We're up and running in Frankfurt. We have a big presence in Paris and in Dublin across the securities business, banking and sales and trading. But it's hard not to be allocating increasing amounts of human intellectual capital and then financial resourcing into Asia.

The internationalization of the Chinese capital markets is an extraordinary thing to witness. We pursue the privatizations of the SOEs about 20 years ago, then we went through the going public phase of Alibaba and Tencent and Meituan. And now, we are at the next stage, where these companies are effectively having cubs and grand cubs that are not only in the regular way technology business to service the Chinese consumer business, but they are global behemoths in health care, in financials, in logistics. So the internationalization of the Chinese capital markets, with the imprimatur of this MSCI [weighting], is something that we are extremely excited about and we will be giving a lot of attention to. That is sort of the regional forced order.

Again, U.S., first and foremost, increasing Asia, and as a global player, we're not going to relent in Europe.

And then in the functional categories, I like elements of all 3. The reality is that the M&A franchise and our underwriting capabilities are superb, but there's more share. We can go after that. If we, now and then, want to bolt-on a banker who can get us C-suite access, we'll do that. But the culture in the investment business banking at the firm is very strong.

If you think about the equities business, the challenge there is to make sure that we are growing revenue, but not diluting returns. If we have competitors that are looking to push us on risk or on margin, we have to hold fast. How do you do that? You need to make sure that you're offering some of these other products I described.

And then the Fixed Income business, what's much important is that we have this ballast of stable revenue. So increasingly, we're thinking about the financing stream. We have a world-class securitized products group, so lending with -- secured lending with high underwriting standards. And what's important, too, then is to use the MSET technology to sort of help us progress as leaders across these markets.

CHINEDU BOLU: Since you brought up technology, let's pivot to technology. I think Morgan Stanley has been at the forefront, especially post-crisis, of innovation -- or that's Project Velocity, MSET, et cetera. When you look -- going forward, when you think about what you invested in today from a technology standpoint, which technologies do you think will have the biggest payoff over the next 5 years?

TED PICK: It's an interesting question. We -- as you say, we have history here in the equities business going back to decimalization and then Reg NMS. And I think you referenced Project Velocity. So this was a mission-critical assignment that we undertook around 2010 after I'd been managing the equities business for about a year. We got together with our MSET team and the business leaders and we decided to effectively double down on the cash agency business. And now, we trade 13% of U.S. advertised daily volume. On busy days, about 1 billion shares a day. That has been, in some respects, a category killer. The key, though, has been to take that MSET technology and the brand and to effectively germinate it across the equities business and then, over time, to think about how we can put that to use in the Fixed Income business.

And so I made reference to this notion of equitizing the Fixed Income business. And I guess the way I would think about it is a barbell. On the one end of the barbell, you are effectively running a robust, resilient kit which prosecutes large volumes and offers you access and liquidity across every connector. And then at the other of the barbell, you have a human capital that leads in offering content and solutions. That barbell, I think, is the vision that will begin to take hold inside of the Fixed Income business as we move the brand, migrating it from what was originally a cash agency business across the equity underlier and then into fixed income.

CHINEDU BOLU: To use your phrase, equitization of FIC, we're seeing a trend of folks like yourself that run the equities business running FIC, but it just seems like that business has had a harder time equitizing.

TED PICK: Right.

CHINEDU BOLU: Kind of when you think about some of the structural barriers, like kind of what are they? And what actually changes like the pace of equitization in that business?

TED PICK: The business has been resistant to electronification. It's true, as you know -- as you well know. We have to consider how varied and complex the fixed income product set is. You're talking about credit, interest rates, foreign exchange, commodities all under 1 umbrella called fixed income.

When I came from my underwriting days to the equities business, I thought "Wow, that is complicated, complex stuff." And then I got introduction of fixed income, and it's seminar-level complexity. Large notionals, convexity, and we know this. And so what happened is that the rate of adoption has not been linear, and it has not been the same for each of the product set. And some of that's been driven by client behavior, where they want to play where they don't. It's also driven by the reality that some of the products are traded on a principal versus agency basis. The spot FX, as we all know, is now traded completely automated.

It's actually the case that 70% of our tickets across fixed income -- not apples-to-apples, but if you just sort of counted every ticket in the fixed-income division as one, 70% of them are executed electronically. But it's only about 1/3 of the volume.

If you think about our cash agency equities business, that number is well over 90%, so there's a heck of a way to go. Now if you took a slice of that, think of investment-grade corporate credit, there, I believe, 34% of the CUSIPs trade less than $1 million a year.

So the task of trying to amalgamate and effectively warehouse and classify all of those CUSIPs requires a lot of technology, a big lift. But it's happening, and it's happening at an accelerating clip. We have world-class effort there. We have a world-class effort in annuities. Same type of dynamic. And the equitization of this product set is not an if; it's a when. And it's happening now.

So the key is, again, to think about the barbell. You will have, over time, say 5 years, you will have, on the end, much of the product set having been equitized. And then at the other end, some of the businesses not meant to be equitized. It is traded over-the-counter. It is highly complex, bespoke over-the-counter, not just in the fact that it's not exchange-driven but it is very much C-suite driven, high sophistication and risk management requirements. And that solution's mentality will sit at the other end of the barbell.

But the rate of equitization for the preponderance of the fixed-income product set, I think, that's a big story that is now kicking in. And for us, the key is that we have this MSET brand. The clients are ready to move. We're moving with them. We have these world-class technology efforts in and around the boxes in fixed-income. And now, we're leveraging that across the markets businesses.

We have front-to-back projects, for example, in structured notes, a laborious process where you look to try to create scale, where each ticket takes a long time to process, where there isn't trade through processing. Or in the loan settlement business, which was a process that would take a month. Now I can see a day when that will take a matter of days. We have these front-to-back projects that are run jointly by our technology business and the business unit leaders as one team.

Now what's important in all of this, of course is, you imagine these kits that allow you to prosecute a lot of volume across many different underliers, you need humans, whether they be [strats], risk managers, business folks to be properly calibrating the risk, make sure on an ongoing basis they're measuring resiliency and making sure that we're executing in a flawless way.

CHINEDU BOLU: Perfect. Let me switch over to the investment bank, the IBD division, which you've just taken over. Obviously, you've had a successful strategy in equities and in the Fixed Income business. What's your vision for the investment bank over the next 5 years?

TED PICK: The 2 thoughts I have there are: one, it's a world-class business. It's a gem. So part of my job is not do anything to make it any less a gem. And if there are folks that we might bolt-on, perhaps there is a bit of capacity or there are product areas where we can expand the effort, so capability, we might add.

The beauty of the 9 box is the beauty of having our leading investment bankers working so well with our folks who run the markets business, which those of you that know the investment banking industry, that in itself is something very positive. You can then imagine that the investment banker can have effectively a two-pronged dialogue. For the control catalyst situation, they're in the boardroom, they're in the C-suite. But there are a panoply of products that need to be sold through the CFO or the Treasurer, risk management, hedging product, and there, we want to be aggressive, bringing our markets people together with our bankers through our world-class underwriting business, our Global Capital Markets Group.

CHINEDU BOLU: You mentioned the investment banking business is already on a very high level. From a manager perspective, do you have a different mentality in terms of how you think about running the business that's already doing well as opposed to the other 2 you took over where you effectively did a turnaround?

TED PICK: They were running -- the other businesses were running reasonably well, truly. Once we got going after the crisis, the team inside of equities, they did a world-class job focusing on the client. They just focused on the client, the firm, gave us some balance sheet to work with to rebuild the prime brokerage. We already had the history and cash that I described, and then we really went after trying to not be an also-ran in the derivatives business. A huge team that put that together, I think, the average tenure on our equity operating committee is 23 years. I was an active observer, but they did that.

The fixed-income turnaround, there, I might argue the team actually did an even more extraordinary job because, there we're not a natural. We're not a natural top 3 players commercial bank. And so the question became an existential one. And for us, we made the decision that we would have a credible business. We have a leadership team that is not only dedicated to managing the business prudently, but so, too, as we did in equities, very much focused on client behavior. And this equitization effect is not just how we behave and it's not just a technology phenomenon. It's, notwithstanding some of the agency-versus-principal differences, the fixed income client set, very much focused on some of the same qualities of content and service that the equities client set is. And the management team and then the core of the Fixed Income business, very much focused on that.

So for a period of time, as you know, while we kept the identity -- I mentioned in the presentation, we did not seek to try to convert the identity of one or the other business. What we sought to do was try to cross-pollinate risk management and some of the leadership techniques where we could actually bring them together in front of the client. And that has been reasonably successful. We think there's more to do.

And then, this type of 9 box mentality now will extend to the investment bankers, who view the folks in the markets businesses as partners. That in this environment, we can continue to take share, but hopefully, too, we're going to get, for the first time in more than a decade, a chance to actually watch the pie increase. That there might be macro opportunities, there might be incremental hedging opportunities. And that is exciting for the business as a whole.

CHINEDU BOLU: Regulation method, so what are we, 18 months post-implementation? If you look at the impact across your business, research, et cetera, kind of how has it affected your business, lesson learned, et cetera?

TED PICK: As it pertains to MiFID, I guess that focuses mainly on what you're speaking to which is the separation, the bifurcation of the advisory product, research from BestX. It began, as we know, as a European phenomenon, some debate about whether for operational reasons some of the lead steer institutional client base would go global. Some of them have. I believe, others might well follow. Others, though, won't.

The implication is that there has been a combination of a withdrawal of some of the research capability in the system as a whole, and then a diminution in the pure advisory product paid out to The Street for providing research. We can all pull up a model. So a lot of what made research worth having 10 years ago is obsolete. Everyone has a model.

So then the question is, do you have a research proposition that's differentiated? And I guess the way I would think about it is, if you thought about your eyeballs on Bloomberg or on the tube, maybe you've seen our name more than you might have 3 years ago, and the answer to that is yes. We actually are steadfast in the delivery of the product. A little bit of countertrend, folks looking at, "Well, what would be the implications to cash margins with the advisory removal?" Our view was, not just for Institutional Securities business, but also for the Wealth Management business, having relevant research makes a difference. Having world-class economists, having strategists, but that, that research couldn't any longer be just a regurgitation of an earnings report, but would have to actually be provocative stuff, forward-thinking about the auto industry, for example, across geographies.

So again, having people work together across research disciplines and then putting out blue papers that the clients grew AI and bots. We can see if they're reading it or not. In fact, they are reading it. They like it. And then that becomes the venue for discussions about whether they want to do other types of business for us. So we have been steadfast here, and we will continue to be.

The question will be whether some of the boutiques who may not have the wherewithal for the other capabilities, whether they will continue to have a role and whether midsized players that have equities businesses that're not PVT positive, whether they will stick with it. I mean there is a possibility that if there is an enough of a diminution of high-quality alpha-generative, or the conduit to alpha-generative sell-side research, that actually we could emerge a winner, helps us to consolidate other revenues as appropriate.

CHINEDU BOLU: Okay. Maybe just last one on the equities business. We have taken share, you are the leader. But every other bank out there or a lot of banks out there trying to take share. How are you able to sort of defend that share over time?

TED PICK: High levels of paranoia led by me, by now, I've bequeathed that mindset to the 3 who are running the business better than I did.

Paranoia. When you're 5 years #1 and there are 1 or 2 competitors we can think of, they're coming after you. How are they coming after you? Well, maybe they're coming after you on price. Maybe they're coming after you on reduced margin, i.e., looser risk requirements for the client base. That's not a game we're going to play. We are going to offer the product at returns on capital that are attractive to the business and to the shareholder. And that balancing act then necessitates that, not only do we continue to offer research, content, advice, but the entire product set. So when there are periods when people are interested in China, when there are periods where the market is defensive and they're looking for hedging techniques, we need to have outside share.

The pressure is on, but the team is used to this and has lavishly focused on where they need to perform in the 9 boxes. And again, as much as it's important to lead in that segment, and it is important to have 20 share, what is more important in terms of overall PVT generation is whether the wallet can resume its correlation to GDP.

I'd add, too, that as we have seen over the years in the fixed-income products set, the barriers to entry to run a large equities business are quite high, and they're growing given the headwinds of automation and regulation. And so there is the possibility that 3 to 5 years out, there will be a smaller set of large equities providers who will be able to increase share through the cycle.

CHINEDU BOLU: Perfect. As you think about PVT optimization and even ROE optimization, the business as a whole, ISG, do think there's still room for incremental expense or capital efficiencies in the broad ISG business?

TED PICK: I think we're in a pretty good place in terms of capital efficiency as you think about where we are on the efficiency frontier. As you know there are various toggles, but we've been on this for a number of years. So I'd say that on capital, whether it's measured by Basel or balance sheet, we feel pretty good about where we are in terms of optimization. In fact, the RWA numbers have gone down over the last several years while our revenues have gone up. So there's a pretty good capital story there.

Expenses, though, you need to stay on it. There's this duality. We want invest through the cycle, but we want to be mindful of the 73% number. And that means that you have to be careful about where you are in fact investing in the client set versus generating inefficiency. Technology spend can be split into run-the-bank process, where we need to make sure we have credible and resilient operations, especially as we get larger and some of these products, especially as the fixed income product set begins to equitize. But then we need to also spend money on changing the bank, which means we need to be thinking about forward technologies. That is something that we spend a considerable a lot of time on.

CHINEDU BOLU: Okay. Maybe one last one here. Talent. It's a people business. And as you think sort of about the competition for talent today and the role that big tech is playing, how is Morgan Stanley staying competitive in terms of your ability to attract the brightest, young talent?

TED PICK: Well, the war for talent is never ending, as it should be. And it is the case that some folks will migrate to technology companies, but we, too, will hire from technology companies, whether they be programmers or folks who can help transform our business. So it's not a material [specter] to departure. There are some. But we saw this phenomenon overheat a little bit in the late '90s, and as we know then, things normalized. But these are great companies, of course. Many of them are our clients, so it stands to reason that they will be interesting competitors.

What's more interesting, though, still, is where you have alternative asset managers or real money asset managers who have embedded technology, private equity firms. And that is of interest to folks who may be looking to do something different than working at a big investment bank.

And there's good news for us. We had 50,000 applications for our 550 summer intern lots that are starting now. I can tell you with high levels of certainty that I don't think I could have gotten a job against these applicants. I'm sure you could have, but I couldn't have. And it's extraordinary.

And we survey well internally, and we survey well externally. Glassdoor has us as a top 5 employer, all good stuff. But the key is to -- if we're talking about juniors, is to keep these kids longer. And they are extraordinarily well informed. So they want to come in, but then, do they want to do something next and when? And so how do we think about that? And we're pivoting on offense. The way we're think about that is show them the firm, give them mobility experience, put them in some of the different circles of the Venn diagram, allow them to see what a trading desk looks like, have then work in research, have them work in securitized products, have them work in the M&A department, and do that early.

And then of course, it's critical to have a class and a group of people who are diverse that reflects society at large, and it's increasingly important for us to be focused on making sure of that -- a place where people feel included and a sense of belonging.

And so of that against a culture of excellence, where we think about doing the right thing. I'm bullish on our ability not only to attract the very best of these kids, but over time to nurture their careers and then to have folks that spend their whole careers at the firm, like I did .

CHINEDU BOLU: Fantastic. This is a great place to stop.

TED PICK: Thank you.

CHINEDU BOLU: Thank you very much, Ted, for your time.

Jan 02, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) CNBC screenshot Moderna Therapeutics had a record-breaking initial public offering[1] in December, but has tumbled 35% from its debut price to about $15 per share. On Wednesday, Wall Street analysts issued their price targets for Moderna. With the exception of JPMorgan and Barclays, all were above Moderna's $23 IPO price. Watch Moderna[2] trade in real time.

The buzzy biotech Moderna broke records with its initial public offering last month, but its track record since has fallen short. Moderna, which is developing messenger RNA-based therapies for cancer, infectious diseases and more, went public at $23 a share in early December. The stock fell in its trading debut[3], and has keep on tumbling since. It now trades for about $15 a share. Wall Street analysts began putting out research reports on the biotech on Wednesday. The reports provide an overview of Moderna's business prospects, and offer an estimate of what the stock is worth. Much of Wall Street has high hopes for the stock, including big-name firms Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. Morgan Stanley had the highest price target among analyst notes reviewed by Business Insider, at $29. "For us, we continue to view the strength of the platform as a major competitive advantage and see data as the clear way to address the bear case," Morgan Stanley wrote. JPMorgan, which helped lead the IPO, was a notable exception. JPMorgan issued a price target of $22 on Wednesday, below Moderna's IPO price tag, though still above where it's trading now.Moderna's valuation is a `sticking point' for JPMorgan"The company's unprecedented valuation has been a sticking point," JPMorgan analyst Cory Kasimov noted, given a crucial risk: that its mRNA medicines may not work. "While we acknowledge this is a long-term story, we believe weakness post-IPO presents a more enticing opportunity." Key Moderna price targets include: Morgan Stanley: $29 Oppenheimer: $27 Goldman Sachs: $25 JPMorgan: $22 Barclays: $20 Read more: Moderna tumbled in its Wall Street debut after the biggest IPO in biotech history[4]Turning the body into a drug factoryA key component of the excitement surrounding Moderna is its technology: messenger RNA, which has long been seen as having enormous potential to treat disease. The idea is that by putting messenger RNA into the body, it can turn the body into a drug factory, pumping out the proteins needed to fight a particular disease like a virus or cancer. Yet turning that potential from theory to practice has been the challenge. Moderna's approach centers around modifying a component of RNA called uridine, so that internal bodily mechanisms won't get in the way of its drugs. Other companies are also working in this area, but Moderna has wowed many on Wall Street with how much it has accomplished in a relatively short amount of time.Moderna doesn't have any drugs on the marketFounded in 2010, the biotech had just one employee when CEO Stphane Bancel joined the following year. Now, though, it has brought 21 drug development programs along, 13 of which are a focus, and has ushered an impressive number of them into clinical trials, according to Oppenheimer analyst Leah Rush Cann. "Moderna has advanced ten compounds into the clinic during this time, an unprecedented number during this time frame for any biotech company previously," Rush Cann said. J.P. Morgan's Kasimov also praised Moderna's 'disruptive platform with a formidable pipeline to match.' Notably, though, Moderna's medicines have not yet been reviewed or approved by US regulators, and aren't expected to be for the next several years. Oppenheimer's Rush Cann, for example, projects that Moderna could bring in its first product revenue in 2024, and estimates that revenue could balloon to $28 billion in 2030.Barclays has the lowest price target for ModernaBarclays analyst Geoff Meacham set a price target at $20 on Wednesday. His thinking: It gives investors a chance to get in now before more data from clinical trials read out. Moderna declined to comment on the price targets. Other investors have been more skeptical of Moderna's success. When sharing her 2019 predictions, Venrock partner Cami Samuels[5] said she's expecting Moderna to exit at a $3 billion valuation. That's less than half of its valuation at the IPO, and even further below where Moderna was trading on Wednesday, when it had around a $5 billion valuation. "It's hard for me, looking at their pipeline, to figure out why they're valued five times, six times [as much as] other companies with the same pipeline," said Samuels, whose firm makes investments in technology and healthcare companies. urn:contentItem:60S5-BHT1-JBTY-W3XF-00000-00Morneau's pitch to OECD: Let me take on giants2020-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:46ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A4Morneau's pitch to OECD: Let me take on giantsHeather Scoffield Toronto Star OPINION

For the longest time, Canada's best hopes for reining in the burgeoning power of Facebook, Google and Big Tech were in the international sphere, leaning on global organizations to negotiate rules where everyone plays along and no one can be singled out.

Our former finance minister, Bill Morneau, will persist with that campaign as he tries to win the top position at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which is consumed with the global talks (such as they are) on digital taxation.

He will pitch himself as a go-between, someone who can bridge deep differences between the United States and the European Union around how to treat Big Tech.

We could hope he makes some headway, but it's a long shot. He is competing against strong candidates. And even if he wins, the international talks are stalled, each side digging in its heels.

It's becoming clearer and clearer, most recently in Australia, that the real decisions need to be made at the national level - and will require some chutzpa.

There's no doubt that reining in the reach and the wealth of Big Tech is a global affair. But waiting for global action is just taking too long.

"Dealing with social media regulation is a global problem," says Fenwick McKelvey of Concordia University in Montreal. "There needs to be a way forward; but there's no clear way forward."

The pandemic economy has amplified the power of the digital behemoths, and the dynamics between so-called FAANG (Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Google) and consumers, the media and the advertisers who rely on digital distribution have become more intense as our nondigital world has shut down.

Domestic media and domestic businesses are paying the price, and the price is rising.

In Canada, concern about the influence of FAANG has mounted steadily. Content providers - Canadian media, entertainment, cultural industries - have struggled and sometimes buckled under even as the platforms that carry their work flourish and expand their influence.

The hope was that countries around the world could come together and decide what to do collectively, to avoid the threat of retaliation from the United States (where the companies are based) or from the companies themselves, now that they're as powerful as some countries.

With strong support from leaders at the G20 and the G7, the OECD is hosting talks on digital taxation. And on the fake-news, hate-speech issues raised by unedited content on social media platforms, Canada was co-operating with the likes of New Zealand and other countries to crack down on terrorist discourse, violence and hatred on the web.

But the digital taxation talks have blown past their deadlines, and the proliferation of fake news and hatred on the web continues. Canadian authorities have made it clear that they're discussing domestic moves, and in the last election, there was a political consensus that Big Tech should pay corporate tax. But so far, they've limited their action to narrow competition concerns and privacy concerns taken up through the courts.

It's no secret why.

It's a love-hate relationship on many levels, and every move to regulate or tax their reach has many ripple effects. Canadian media and creative industries don't usually get paid for the use of their content on social media platforms, but they need the platforms to distribute their content. Canadian politicians don't like the misinformation or bias spread by social media, but they rely on social media to spread their own messages.

Canadian consumers may lament the disappearance of local products, but they love the convenience of online shopping.

Corporate self-interest blurs and conflates with the public interest in so many of these discussions that it's difficult to separate them out.

Several European countries have taken matters into their own hands, but it's Australia's example that is an informative but cautionary tale for Canada.

Similar in size and power to Canada, Australia turned to its competition authority to order Facebook and Google to negotiate a deal with some Australian media to pay for content. Facebook has balked and said it just won't carry Australian news if forced to pay.

But rather than run scared, Canadian decision-makers could look to Australia for a real-time read on how far Facebook and Google can be pushed before they pull away and refuse to do business, McKelvey says. We can learn the price of taking them on, and figure out how much we can stomach.

Canada should also be looking at how Australia has flexed its oversight-of-competition muscles to get to Big Tech, says Sara Bannerman, a McMaster University associate professor and research chair in communication policy and governance.

Canada's main approach has been to focus on copyright infringements and how copyright law can be used to ensure web platforms don't take creative content unfairly, she says. But Australia looked at the issues through the prism of competition, focusing on the relative bargaining power of Big Tech and domestic media, and acting as a referee in mandated negotiations.

It's an interesting approach to a difficult set of problems, she says, and something Canada could learn from.

And given the slow pace of global talks and the iffy prospect of a Morneau leadership at the OECD, it's probably a much faster route than hoping international organizations figure it out for us.

Twitter: @hscoffield

Multinational tech giants keep getting bigger at the expense of domestic media and competitiveness. Defanging Big Tech is an ongoing series examining the challenge for governments, and how they should respond.

Cracks Appear in Europe’s Stance on Greece | Chinese Market Rout Hits Ordinary Investors | Ex-Goldman Programmer’s 2nd Conviction Overturned | Too Many Angels?

CRACKS APPEAR IN EUROPE'S STANCE ON GREECE | A day after Greek voters rejected the bailout terms set by creditors, a rift emerged among European leaders as Germany maintained its hard line with Athens while other officials signaled a willingness to look for a compromise, Liz Alderman and Jack Ewing write in The New York Times. In France, the finance minister, Michel Sapin, told French radio on Monday that France could support debt relief for Greece should the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, put forth a proposal containing "serious" terms for a new bailout package. And in Brussels, the European Commission's vice president for euro affairs, Valdis Dombrovskis, said, "If all sides are working seriously, it's possible to find a solution, even in this very complicated situation."

After President François Hollande of France and Angela Merkel, Germany's chancellor, met in Paris on Monday, each leader said Europe was open to negotiations with Greece, but Ms. Merkel struck a tougher tone, Alison Smale and Andrew Higgins write in The New York Times. "She said that just as Greek voters had a right to make their voices heard, the views of other democracies in the European Union also have to be respected," they write. Europe had offered Greece a "generous" bailout deal, she said, and now it was up to Mr. Tsipras to present "very specific proposals." (The New York Times has   compiled a chart listing the key players' stances on the Greek debt crisis.)

The European Central Bank also added more pressure on Greece on Monday as it toughened the collateral terms for Greek banks that seek to tap into an emergency credit line, The Financial Times reports. The E.C.B. kept the credit line limit at (EURO)89 billion, or $98 billion, but that would not necessarily be enough to keep money flowing to depositors, Ms. Alderman and Mr. Ewing write. The Greek government extended a weeklong bank holiday through Wednesday and said that a withdrawal cap of (EURO)60, or $67, per day from A.T.M.s could be tightened.

With Euclid Tsakalotos, an Oxford-educated economist, replacing Yanis Varoufakis as Greece's finance minister, Mr. Tsipras is preparing to present new debt proposals on Tuesday, when eurozone leaders are to meet in Brussels at 6 p.m. (noon E.D.T.). The eurozone finance ministers will meet earlier in the day at 1 p.m. (7 a.m. E.D.T.).

CHINESE MARKET ROUT HITS ORDINARY INVESTORS | Chinese stocks resumed their decline on Tuesday, despite the Chinese government's effort to prop up the country's stock markets over the weekend, and ordinary investors are bracing for a wild ride, David Barboza writes in DealBook. "What happened in China over the last year looks like another episode of the madness of crowds, when many investors seem to lose their senses," he writes. "They started to borrow money on margin to buy shares they couldn't afford. They bet everything on the belief that this was a new era, gleefully believing stocks moved in only one direction." This sort of blind optimism is not unique to Chinese investors, but Mr. Barboza notes a key difference between markets in China and those in big economies like the United States: "In China, mom-and-pop investors, rather than big institutions, make up the bulk of stock purchases." And the ordinary investor doesn't have the same resources as the big institutions to ride out the volatility of the markets, he writes.

What makes matters worse is that the market drop comes at a time when the Chinese economy has weakened considerably and many local governments are deep into debt. The government is now worried about the social and political repercussions of a sustained fall in the markets. And yet, some investors, like Chen Minliang of Shanghai, are still undeterred. "Honestly, my confidence in regulators and the market is diminishing," the publishing house editor told Mr. Barboza. "But I still think the market itself has some rules and will likely rebound after reaching the floor." (For other views on the Chinese markets, see Neil Irwin's take in The Upshot and   Peter Thal Larsen's post for Breakingviews.)

EX-GOLDMAN PROGRAMMER'S 2ND CONVICTION OVERTURNED | On Monday, Sergey Aleynikov, a former Goldman Sachs programmer, won a dismissal of his conviction on a charge that he stole confidential computer code for Goldman Sachs's high-speed trading business, Matthew Goldstein writes in DealBook. This was the second time Mr. Aleynikov prevailed in court. After Mr. Aleynikov was found guilty of stealing proprietary code in December 2010, a federal appellate court in 2012 overturned the conviction under a federal corporate espionage law, ruling that federal prosecutors in Manhattan had misapplied the law.

Then state prosecutors in Manhattan charged him with violating state computer-theft-related laws, and Mr. Aleynikov was found guilty on one count. On Monday, Justice Daniel P. Conviser of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Monday overturned that conviction, ruling that the decades-old state law that Mr. Aleynikov was found guilty of violating did not apply to the accusations against him. State prosecutors in Manhattan have already indicated they may appeal the decision.

ON THE AGENDA | The Department of Commerce will release the latest data on the trade balance in May at 8:30 a.m. John Legere, T-Mobile's chief executive, is scheduled to appear on CNBC at 5 p.m.

TOO MANY ANGELS? | As wealthy individuals clamor to be a part of the hot start-ups before they get big, tech entrepreneurs are finding that there can be downsides to having too many angel investors, Mike Isaac writes in The New York Times. "When many angels are involved, for example, no one investor may feel compelled to help the company if it runs into trouble," he writes. "Yet at the same time, having a dozen or more on-the-ground investors can also mean a dozen or more opinions about company strategy."

Too many angels can also be taken as an indication that a company is not strong enough to attract a lead investor, said Nancy Hua of Apptimize. And Mr. Isaac notes that many angel investors who haven't done their due diligence may not know the exact health of their start-up when asked by others, which can give the perception that the company is not doing well. "That communication overhead isn't something I'd realized would happen beforehand," Ms. Hua said.

Puerto Rico to Miss Largest Payment to Date | China Lending Sends Egg Futures Soaring

HALLIBURTON AND BAKER HUGHES CALL OFF MERGER | The oil services providers Halliburton and Baker Hughes have called off their $35 billion merger,
Leslie Picker reports in DealBook. A person briefed on the matter said the decision came after a long regulatory review that ended with the Justice Department seeking to block the deal.

Bloomberg, which had reported that the deal would be terminated, reported that the United States attorney general, Loretta E. Lynch, said "The companies' decision to abandon this transaction - which would have left many oilfield service markets in the hands of a duopoly - is a victory for the U.S. economy and for all Americans."

"While both companies expected the proposed merger to result in compelling benefits to shareholders, customers and other stakeholders, challenges in obtaining remaining regulatory approvals and general industry conditions that severely damaged deal economics led to the conclusion that termination is the best course of action," David Lesar, Halliburton's chairman, said in a news release.

Halliburton will have to pay Baker Hughes a $3.5 billion breakup fee - one of the biggest termination fees ever. The fee was written into the merger agreement to reassure Baker Hughes that Halliburton expected the deal to be completed.

Since the merger was announced in November 2014, commodity prices have plummeted and sent many energy companies into a tailspin. Merging these two oil services companies may have helped with some of the effects of deteriorating commodity prices, but the Justice Department last month sued to block the deal. It said it would "eliminate vital competition, skew energy markets and harm American consumers."

PUERTO RICO TO MISS LARGEST PAYMENT TO DATE | Gov. Alejandro García Padilla of Puerto Rico said Sunday that he had ordered a debt moratorium, blocking a $422 million payment due on Monday,
Mary Williams Walsh reports in The New York Times.

This would be the biggest payment that Puerto Rico had missed and indicates that it is also likely to default on even larger and more consequential payments due on July 1, unless Congress enacts rescue legislation in time.

"This was a painful decision," the governor said in a speech on Sunday, in which he struck a nationalistic tone and said he had to invoke his emergency powers under Puerto Rican law because help from Washington was not coming. "We would have preferred to have had a legal framework to restructure our debts in an orderly manner."

Nearly $2 billion is due at the beginning of July and about $800 million of it consists of general obligation bonds that carry an explicit guarantee by the Puerto Rican Constitution. Missing that payment would set off a wave of creditor lawsuits and cast a shadow over America's $3.7 trillion municipal bond market, which has been an essential source of financing for public works.

In his speech, the governor said that rescue legislation was too slow and blamed unnamed "opponents of the people of Puerto Rico," saying that they "unleashed a brutal campaign of racial discrimination and lies against us" and convincing some members of Congress that Puerto Rico needed austerity rather than debt relief.

"Puerto Rico needs Speaker Paul Ryan to exercise his leadership and honor his word," he added. "We can't wait any longer. We need this restructuring mechanism now."

CHINA LENDING SENDS EGG FUTURES SOARING | China has poured hundreds of billions of dollars into its economy in a bid to support growth and a lending deluge has sent money into some unexpected places,
Neil Gough reports in DealBook.

At a financial market in Dalian, where investors can place bets on the future productivity of the country's hens, egg futures have surged by as much as one-third since March. This might be justified if investors were expecting an end to China's chicken flocks, but the market's usual participants say the chickens are fine. Indeed, the actual price of eggs in the country's markets has fallen from a year ago, according to government statistics.

China is the world's biggest producer of eggs, but it is not clear whether the investment surge in eggs will have an impact on real-world prices, as futures prices can take months to trickle down to the real world. If it subsides, the price of eggs in local markets may not move.

Eggs are not the only commodity out of kilter - domestic prices and trading volumes for steel, garlic, cotton, iron ore and other items have soared despite demand being dampened by China's economic slowdown.

Economists blame Beijing's efforts to shore up the economy. China has a tendency to experience investment bubbles when the government steps up spending and lending - previous efforts to bolster growth have created unexplained rises and striking drops in the real estate and stock market.

Government officials increased lending by state-controlled banks and offered other support measures in the first few months of the year as economic growth slowed and longtime drivers like manufacturing and exports showed continued weakness.

In the short term, the lending may be good for global growth, but China risks adding to its already fast-growing pile of debt, which is nearly 300 percent of gross domestic product by some estimates.

It seems that policy makers have set aside their concerns about the debt burden for now, but by delaying a move to wean itself off cheap credit, China may be setting itself up for even more problems.
